qas.question: Where do pharmacists acquire more preparation following pharmacy school?
What do clinical pharmacists specialize in?
What is one issue that adds to the complexity of a pharmacist's job?
Which pharmacists are likely to seek additional education following pharmacy school?
Where do pharmacists not go following pharmacy school?
What do clinical pharmacists not specialize in?
What is one issue that takes away the complexity of a pharmacist's job?
Which pharmacists never seek additional education following pharmacy school?

context: Because of the complexity of medications including specific indications, <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b6_0>effectiveness of treatment regimens<b6_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, safety of medications (i.e., drug interactions) and patient compliance issues (in the hospital and at home) many <a3_0><a3_1><b7_0>pharmacists practicing in hospitals<b7_0/><a3_1/><a3_0/> gain more education and training after pharmacy school through <a0_0><b4_0>a <a0_1><a0_2>pharmacy practice residency<b4_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> and sometimes followed by another residency in a specific area. Those pharmacists are often referred to as <a3_2>clinical pharmacists<a3_2/> and they often specialize in <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b5_0>various disciplines of pharmacy<b5_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>. For example, there are pharmacists who specialize in hematology/oncology, HIV/AIDS, infectious disease, critical care, emergency medicine, toxicology, nuclear pharmacy, pain management, psychiatry, anti-coagulation clinics, herbal medicine, neurology/epilepsy management, pediatrics, neonatal pharmacists and more.
